Rhododendron vialii is a species of evergreen shrub belonging to the family Ericaceae. It is native to southwestern China, particularly in the Yunnan and Sichuan provinces.

The plant typically grows to a height of 1-3 meters and has a dense, compact growth habit. The leaves are oblong to lanceolate in shape, measuring around 8-15 cm in length, and have a leathery texture with a glossy upper surface.

The flowers of Rhododendron vialii are the most distinctive feature of this species. They are typically borne in clusters of 5-10 and have a unique coloration, with the outer petals being bright red or scarlet, while the inner petals are a contrasting yellow or orange. The flowers have a tubular shape and can reach up to 5 cm in length.

This species is adapted to grow in cool, moist, and shaded environments, such as montane forests and alpine meadows. It is often found at elevations ranging from 2,000 to 4,000 meters above sea level.

Rhododendron vialii is considered a horticultural ornamental and is valued for its striking floral displays. It is also known to have some medicinal properties and has been used in traditional Chinese medicine.
